title: Australian Open Day 1 live updates, schedules, highlights
description: Day 1 of the 2025 Australian Open is underway, and we're at Melbourne Park bringing you the best news, latest results, schedules and more.
author: ESPN Staff

title: 'We are so back': Can a laser-focused Coco Gauff win the Australian Open?
description: After a disappointing US Open, Coco Gauff made changes to her game and her coaching staff. The results have been undeniable.
author: D'Arcy Maine

title: Unlock the Perfect Slice Serve - Essential Tennis Podcast #415
description: The wide slice serve is a CRITICAL tool to have in your tool box. It pulls opponents out of position, opens the court up for you to hit into, exposes their usually weaker backhand side, and forces them to run twice as far for the next shot - if they even get it at all. Let’s take a deep dive into how YOU can develop this powerful weapon, step by step in this special episode of the Essential Tennis Podcast.
author: Essential Tennis LLC

title: 3 Djokovic Secrets To Winning More Matches - Essential Tennis Podcast #414
description: In this special episode of the Essential Tennis Podcast, you're going to learn the top 3 tactical secrets of Novak Djokovic that you can apply in your very next match. Use these tools to gain precision, consistency, and offense to make your opponents more uncomfortable, win more points, and win more matches.
author: Essential Tennis LLC

title: Five Australian Open storylines to watch out for
description: The star names have arrived at the Australian Open for a season-opening Grand Slam which has already thrown up intriguing storylines.

title: 'I didn't know how much fight I had' - why GB's Burrage almost quit tennis
description: Britain's Jodie Burrage says she came to close to quitting tennis last year as she fought back from another serious injury setback.

title: ATP No. 1 Club: Sinner thrives under the weight of being World No. 1
description: Shakespeare wrote that 'uneasy lies the head that wears a crown'. Jannik Sinner, however, may take issue with that signature line from Henry IV Part 2. The Italian has flourished since becoming the sport’s leading man since rising to No. 1 in the PIF ATP Rankings on 10 June last year. Despite playing with extra pressure and expectation, Sinner has produced some jaw-dropping numbers in the past 31 weeks. There are many reasons to believe the dominance will continue in 2025, beginning with the Australian Open. Since becoming the first Italian man and 29th player in history (since 1973) to rise to the top, Sinner has amassed a 40-3 match record according to the Infosys ATP Win/Loss Index. That 93 per cent winning rate compares favourably to his career win/loss mark of 76.7 per cent. Of the eight tournaments he played last year as World No. 1, Sinner won five: Halle, Cincinnati, US Open, Shanghai and the Nitto ATP Finals. He also spearheaded Italy’s triumphant Davis Cup title defense. [ATP APP] Despite the success, Sinner still reflects on 2024 as somewhat of a learning year and indicated that he’ll be even better equipped to handle the pressure of being No. 1 in the new season. “With 23 years old, you don't know exactly what the right thing is to do sometimes. I think I learned from last year,” Sinner said on the eve of his Australian Open title defense. “We're going to make it much, much better also this year.”  Sinner As World No. 1 Match Record  40-3 Win Rate  93%  Titles  5 (from 8 events) Sinner’s remarkable success during his reign at No. 1 contrasts with the early struggles his great rival Carlos Alcaraz had after he ascended to No. 1 for the first time by winning the 2022 US Open. The Spaniard notched a modest 6-4 match record post-US Open through the Rolex Paris Masters, where injury brought an early end to his season. He surrendered top spot at the beginning of the 2023 Australian Open, which he was unable to play. For Sinner, it’s been nothing but sunshine. “It was a massive change. Many, many things have changed,” he said. “Last year there were so many first times. Not only first time winning Grand Slam, but also the year before first time of Davis Cup. Then after becoming World No. 1, then winning also the year-end [Nitto ATP] Finals.” Regardless of results at the Australian Open, Sinner is guaranteed to increase his streak to 34 weeks in his initial streak as No. 1. Just four players spent more than 52 weeks in their debut at No. 1: Roger Federer (237 weeks), Jimmy Connors (160), Lleyton Hewitt (75) and Novak Djokovic (53). [NEWSLETTER FORM]

title: PAC Diary: Munar reflects on first ATP Player Advisory Council meeting of 2025
description: The first meeting of the 2025 ATP Player Advisory Council was held Friday evening in Melbourne ahead of the Australian Open. Pedro Martinez, Andrey Rublev, Camilo Ugo Carabelli, Andrea Vavassori and Jaume Munar are newly elected members of the Council for two-year terms (2025-2026), joining Alexander Zverev, Mackenzie McDonald, Dusan Lajovic, Miguel Reyes-Varela and Matthew Ebden. Throughout the season, members of the Player Advisory Council will write a diary for ATPTour.com bringing fans closer to the hard work the players do behind the scenes to help elevate the sport. This time, new PAC member Jaume Munar picks up the pen. # # # Hello everyone, happy new year and I hope you are all excited for the new season just like we are! I am so happy to be part of the ATP Player Advisory Council for the first time. It was a long time ago that I started thinking of trying to be a Council member. I am 27, but I have always wanted to help the players and present our opinions on every matter possible on Tour. I have gained experience over the past seven years and I hope to use that to be helpful for the ATP. I know quite a lot of people from the players' side to talk to whom I can discuss important topics and I feel confident that I can do a really good job here. I was in touch with Rafael Nadal, a former member of the Council, a lot during the last year of his career and I know the path he and all the people on the Council took. It’s such a good thing to have the opportunity to follow in their footsteps and keep growing the sport. It is a lot of responsibility to be a member of the Council, but at the end, it is more than just us — we are only voices here in the Council. The real responsibility is with all the players to get involved, to try to understand the situations we are dealing with and to try to move forward to deliver for the members and to improve the standards in different areas. The first meeting was nice. I have known most of the people here for a long time, so it felt normal to be part of the group. I was taking notes and trying to put myself in a position to help others. I think it is important for me to have an opinion in these meetings, to be the voice of everyone who elected me and to put the new and fresh ideas on the table to move forward. The relationship with the other players should go both ways. I represent them, so I know how important it is to provide the members with information so they are fully aware of what is going on with the Tour and so they can feel confident in us. I would also be happy if they give me their thoughts and ideas to bring to the Council so that everyone can have their voices heard. It is giving something to receive something. That’s how I feel about being on the Council and to be a representative for everybody here. I just want to be a good member of the council and to have the chance to move forward in the topics that matter the most. In this meeting, I was able to rely on my own experiences when we discussed the ATP Challenger Tour and provide my perspective. Explaining my mindset as a player not only helps my fellow Council members and our Player Board representatives understand things that might not affect them as directly, but it also gives ATP leadership more insight to help them continue improving the product. During my career I have taken online classes and always do everything I can to learn outside of tennis. To keep educating yourself, to keep learning — not just on the court — is very important. It is nice and it really makes my journey more rewarding and I really want to keep improving in all the areas I can. This is just one more step in my life. We are tennis players today, but we don’t know where we will be tomorrow, and I hope to bring that mindset to our meetings. Fans see us competing our hardest in front of millions of fans around the world. But we are humans, too. We have a future after tennis. We have a family and a life. I want fans to know that I have clear ideas, I have priorities in my life. Tennis is of course one, but it is not the only one. I feel like everything I can do outside of tennis is important and that’s why I dedicate so much time to other things like the Council. I am looking forward to a great year ahead. [NEWSLETTER FORM]

title: Australian Open Draw 2025
description: The 2025 Australian Open is upon us, and the draw took place on Thursday evening in Melbourne.  All the big names are present, with defending champion Jannik Sinner the top seed. While Zverev’s strong end to the season bumped him up to the second-seed position. Ten-time Australian Open champions Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz landed …
author: Jonathan

title: Sinner Cruises to ATP Finals Victory
description: Jannik Sinner is the 2024 Nitto ATP finals champion after comfortably defeating Taylor Fritz 6-4 6-4 in Sunday’s final, becoming the first player from his country to win the tournament in its 55-year history. The Italian emerges as the undefeated champion (without even dropping a set) and wins $4,881,100 in prize money, making it a …
author: Jonathan
